articles.headline: Lawmakers Aim to Stop Defense Cuts if Debt Panel Fails
articles.snippet: Pessimism is mounting about whether a committee in Congress can come up with a deal to avoid triggering automatic cuts.
articles.abstract: Pessimism is mounting about whether a committee in Congress can come up with a deal to avoid triggering automatic cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As pessimism mounted this week over the ability of a bipartisan Congressional committee to agree on a deficit-reduction plan, lawmakers began taking steps to head off the large cuts in Pentagon spending that would automatically result from the panel’s failure.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Robert Pear

articles.headline: A C.E.O.’s Support System, a k a Husband
articles.snippet: Aspirants to America’s top corporate jobs need to have a spouse, partner or someone else willing to be devoted to the aspirant’s career. That’s often harder for women.
articles.abstract: Aspirants to America’s top corporate jobs need to have a spouse, partner or someone else willing to be devoted to the aspirant’s career. That’s often harder for women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s to Mark Rometty.

articles.headline: Cain Accuser Tells of Pattern of Behavior, Lawyer Attests
articles.snippet: Multiple incidents of “inappropriate behaviors and unwanted advances” led to a formal complaint, a woman’s lawyer said.
articles.abstract: Multiple incidents of “inappropriate behaviors and unwanted advances” led to a formal complaint, a woman’s lawyer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lawyer for one of the women who accused Herman Cain of sexual harassment said Friday that Mr. Cain engaged in a “series of inappropriate behaviors and unwanted advances” toward his client over two months in the 1990s, and he directly accused Mr. Cain, a Republican presidential candidate, of not telling the truth about his behavior.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Wows Educators, and Woos Them
articles.snippet: Apple in particular used a state-of-the art sales operation that some say is unique, but is raising some concerns.
articles.abstract: Apple in particular used a state-of-the art sales operation that some say is unique, but is raising some concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Three times over the last two years, school officials from Little Falls, Minn., have escaped the winter cold for two-day trips to Silicon Valley. Their destination: the headquarters of Apple.

articles.headline: MF Global Clients Fear for What They Left
articles.snippet: When MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Monday, it left about 150,000 accounts in limbo, with regulators struggling to recover the funds.
articles.abstract: When MF Global filed for bankruptcy on Monday, it left about 150,000 accounts in limbo, with regulators struggling to recover the funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Igor Gavrylov of Kiev, Ukraine, had about $100,000 at MF Global when it collapsed on Monday, although he managed to pull out $150,000 last week.

articles.headline: Taming Unruly Wind Power
articles.snippet: After experiencing energy excesses that could have caused blackouts, utilities in the Northwest asked consumers to participate in a program in which they store surplus electricity at home.
articles.abstract: After experiencing energy excesses that could have caused blackouts, utilities in the Northwest asked consumers to participate in a program in which they store surplus electricity at home.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, electric companies have swung into emergency mode when demand soars on blistering hot days, appealing to households to use less power. But with the rise of wind energy, utilities in the Pacific Northwest are sometimes dealing with the opposite: moments when there is too much electricity for the grid to soak up.

articles.headline: Brazil’s Long Shadow Vexes Some Neighbors
articles.snippet: As Brazil projects its growing economic power across Latin America, it is being met with wariness and protesters.
articles.abstract: As Brazil projects its growing economic power across Latin America, it is being met with wariness and protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — Sandal-clad indigenous protesters have excoriated their president, calling him a “lackey of Brazil.” Angry demonstrations in front of Brazil’s embassy here denounced its “imperialist” tendencies. Bolivian intellectuals lambasted the “São Paulo bourgeoisie,” likening them to the slave hunters who expanded the boundaries of colonial Brazil.

articles.headline: Sad Proof of Europe’s Fallout
articles.snippet: So who says that American financial institutions have little to no exposure to the problems across the Atlantic? The MF Global mess shows otherwise.
articles.abstract: So who says that American financial institutions have little to no exposure to the problems across the Atlantic? The MF Global mess shows otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHO you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?

articles.headline: The Denials That Trapped Greece
articles.snippet: For two years, European politicians, policy makers and bankers underestimated dangers to Greece that seem clear enough in hindsight.
articles.abstract: For two years, European politicians, policy makers and bankers underestimated dangers to Greece that seem clear enough in hindsight.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS —   The warning was clear: Greece was spiraling out of control.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: A King of Connections Is Tech’s Go-To Guy
articles.snippet: Reid Hoffman, the co-founder of LinkedIn, is looking ahead to Web 3.0, even as he juggles a myriad commitments to the present-day Internet.
articles.abstract: Reid Hoffman, the co-founder of LinkedIn, is looking ahead to Web 3.0, even as he juggles a myriad commitments to the present-day Internet.

articles.headline: Leaving Iraq, U.S. Fears New Surge of Qaeda Terror
articles.snippet: Al Qaeda is shifting its tactics and strategies to exploit gaps left by the departing American troops in an attempt to reignite sectarian violence in the country.
articles.abstract: Al Qaeda is shifting its tactics and strategies to exploit gaps left by the departing American troops in an attempt to reignite sectarian violence in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As the United States prepares to withdraw its troops from Iraq by year’s end, senior American and Iraqi officials are expressing growing concern that Al Qaeda’s offshoot here, which just a few years ago waged a debilitating insurgency that plunged the country into a civil war, is poised for a deadly resurgence.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Romney, Always Campaigning for Others ... and for Himself
articles.snippet: Even candidates for minor, obscure offices have found themselves the recipients of Mr. Romney’s money and time.
articles.abstract: Even candidates for minor, obscure offices have found themselves the recipients of Mr. Romney’s money and time.
articles.lead_paragraph: State auditors, county commissioners, sheriffs: no Republican candidate, it seems, has been insignificant enough to escape the glow of Mitt Romney’s affections.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: The Gridlock Where Debts Meet Politics
articles.snippet: Economies in the United States and Europe have been growing too slowly, for too long, to pay for the coming bulge of retirees.
articles.abstract: Economies in the United States and Europe have been growing too slowly, for too long, to pay for the coming bulge of retirees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Greece struggling to form a government that can force harsh austerity measures onto a weary public, Europe is in usual form, taking a couple of steps toward solving its fiscal crisis and then a couple of steps backward. Washington, meanwhile, is hoping that the latest deficit-reduction committee in Congress can succeed where others have failed.

articles.headline: Relenting on Car Sales, Cuba Turns Notorious Clunkers Into Gold
articles.snippet: A new government rule allows Cubans to buy and sell used vehicles freely for the first time in half a century, part of President Raúl Castro’s effort to remodel a hobbled economy and spur the private sector.
articles.abstract: A new government rule allows Cubans to buy and sell used vehicles freely for the first time in half a century, part of President Raúl Castro’s effort to remodel a hobbled economy and spur the private sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Until a few weeks ago, Erik González’s decrepit car did little more than devour his tiny income. He spent hundreds of dollars fixing the car, a 30-year-old Moskvich that his grandfather passed down to him in 2000. Even when it worked, Mr. González could rarely afford to buy gas.

articles.headline: Thailand Flooding Cripples Hard-Drive Suppliers
articles.snippet: The flooding has revealed to the world the scale of Thailand’s industrialization and the extent to which two global industries, computers and cars, rely on components made here.
articles.abstract: The flooding has revealed to the world the scale of Thailand’s industrialization and the extent to which two global industries, computers and cars, rely on components made here.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANG PA-IN, Thailand — In the neck-deep floodwaters of an industrial zone here, workers are using Jet Skis and wooden skiffs to transport stacks of computer components out of waterlogged factories.

articles.headline: Greek Leaders Reach Deal to Form a New Government
articles.snippet: Prime Minister George Papandreou and his chief rival agreed to create a new government, under a new prime minister, appearing to break a deadlock that had paralyzed Greece.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister George Papandreou and his chief rival agreed to create a new government, under a new prime minister, appearing to break a deadlock that had paralyzed Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister George A. Papandreou and his chief rival agreed Sunday night to create a new unity government, under a new prime minister, that will move ahead with the country’s debt-relief deal with the European Union and then hold new elections. Mr. Papandreou agreed to resign once the details are completed on Monday.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Niki Kitsantonis

articles.headline: Weighing Pentagon Cuts, Panetta Faces Deep Pressures
articles.snippet: Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once considered sacrosanct.
articles.abstract: Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once considered sacrosanct.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under orders to cut the Pentagon budget by more than $450 billion over the next decade, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is considering reductions in spending categories once thought sacrosanct, especially in medical and retirement benefits, as well as further shrinking the number of troops and reducing new weapons purchases.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Bit by Bit, Work Exchange Site Aims to Get Jobs Done
articles.snippet: The creator of Second Life built the software for his new work exchange site, Coffee and Power, by hiring programmers from around the world and dividing up the work into small tasks.
articles.abstract: The creator of Second Life built the software for his new work exchange site, Coffee and Power, by hiring programmers from around the world and dividing up the work into small tasks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Philip Rosedale tried to change the nature of play with Second Life, a virtual world of colorful online avatars that got a lot of attention a few years ago.

articles.headline: Delicate Dance of Daytime
articles.snippet: Anderson Cooper’s biggest challenge in his new talk show is embracing the vulgarity of daytime talk without hurting the rest of his career.
articles.abstract: Anderson Cooper’s biggest challenge in his new talk show is embracing the vulgarity of daytime talk without hurting the rest of his career.
articles.lead_paragraph: I had a dream about Anderson Cooper the other night. He was in a vast, cavernous studio and was hanging from the ceiling in a harness, far above the stage.

articles.headline: For Markets in Europe, the Focus of Fear Moves to Italy
articles.snippet: Efforts to solve a growing sovereign debt crisis have failed to quell market unease, and uncertainty in Greece points to continued volatility this week.
articles.abstract: Efforts to solve a growing sovereign debt crisis have failed to quell market unease, and uncertainty in Greece points to continued volatility this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: European efforts to solve a growing sovereign debt crisis have failed to quell market unease on the Continent, and the skepticism over Greece points to continued volatility this week.

articles.headline: Pushing China’s Limits on Web, if Not on Paper
articles.snippet: Murong Xuecun, a popular Chinese novelist, often runs afoul of censors, which has pushed him to become a vocal critic of censorship in China and driven him to publish on the Internet.
articles.abstract: Murong Xuecun, a popular Chinese novelist, often runs afoul of censors, which has pushed him to become a vocal critic of censorship in China and driven him to publish on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When the novelist Murong Xuecun showed up at a ceremony here late last year to collect his first literary prize, he clutched a sheet of paper with some of the most incendiary words he had ever written.

articles.headline: NBC Struggles for Its Footing
articles.snippet: While other networks have generated new hits, NBC has not, and the network’s new leadership has made clear to its staff that rebuilding will take time and patience.
articles.abstract: While other networks have generated new hits, NBC has not, and the network’s new leadership has made clear to its staff that rebuilding will take time and patience.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coming into a new television season, about the only solace for the new management regime at NBC was that the network’s prime-time fortunes had been so bad for so long, things could not get much worse.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: D.E.A. Squads Extend Reach of Drug War
articles.snippet: The United States Drug Enforcement Administration now has five commando-style squads it has been quietly deploying to Western Hemisphere nations that are battling drug cartels.
articles.abstract: The United States Drug Enforcement Administration now has five commando-style squads it has been quietly deploying to Western Hemisphere nations that are battling drug cartels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Late on a moonless night last March, a plane smuggling nearly half a ton of cocaine touched down at a remote airstrip in Honduras. A heavily armed ground crew was waiting for it — as were Honduran security forces. After a 20-minute firefight, a Honduran officer was wounded and two drug traffickers lay dead.

articles.headline: Preaching Virtue of Spanking, Even as Deaths Fuel Debate
articles.snippet: Three children have died in recent years, allegedly at the hands of parents who had a child-rearing book by the preacher Michael Pearl, who advocates physical punishment.
articles.abstract: Three children have died in recent years, allegedly at the hands of parents who had a child-rearing book by the preacher Michael Pearl, who advocates physical punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLEASANTVILLE, Tenn. — After services at the Church at Cane Creek on a recent Sunday, a few dozen families held a potluck picnic and giggling children played pin the tail on the donkey.

articles.headline: A Hidden Toll as States Shift to Contract Workers
articles.snippet: A Michigan plan to replace state employees at a veterans’ facility with contract workers highlights the difficulty of outsourcing in the face of strained budgets.
articles.abstract: A Michigan plan to replace state employees at a veterans’ facility with contract workers highlights the difficulty of outsourcing in the face of strained budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Like many states and local governments struggling to cut costs, Michigan hopes to replace some government employees with contract workers who will do the same job for less.

articles.headline: Disney and YouTube Make a Video Deal
articles.snippet: Both of the companies are betting that a new partnership will help them surmount separate but equally worrisome hurdles.
articles.abstract: Both of the companies are betting that a new partnership will help them surmount separate but equally worrisome hurdles.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two powerful media companies, the Walt Disney Company and YouTube, are betting that a new partnership will help them surmount separate but equally worrisome hurdles as they each strive for greater Web dominance.
